choices: I thank the reviewers, and leave it at that
I follow the reviewers' suggestions
I don't follow the reviewers' suggestions, and email them why
Any other experience that the reader (writer!) has had
1.content:
I've written a poem, and I want to share it with someone. I'm not sure whom to share it with. It's very personal, I can't show it to friends or family. I share a lot of my writing with them, but this one will get them emotional, their reactions won't be to my writing, more likely, they'll respond to the sentiments expressed in the poem. I want someone who'll respond to the content and the writing.

Though quite computer un-savvy, I decide to go to the internet, and I search "Free Poetry Contest". (I don't have a credit card, to pay online, and besides, I don't really want to spend money to share my poem anyway!)

I click on some of the results, they're not really free, those sites.

Then - the screen goes pale yellow, and blue and black writing shows up. A little hesitantly, I fill in the information required.

Suddenly - woooo - My poem is online! I have a black portfolio! I'm a registered author! I have a hundred gift points in my account (What are gift points? I wonder.)

An hour later, I log on again. I rub my eyes in disbelief. I have some new emails. Someone emailed me on the site? Must be a mistake somewhere. I've been here an hour, nobody even knows me yet! I read the emails. Praises and suggestions for my writing. Encouragement. More gift points (I wish I knew what gift points are!)

I read the reviews. I wonder whether to follow the suggestions ...
1.title: First Foray

choices: I decide to buck up and look at how to use the site.
I click the chat button to see where it takes me.
I decide to write another poem.
I do something else... (that the author has done).
11.content:
There are so many good suggestions on how to improve my poem that I stare at the computer for a minute, overwhelmed. I didn't expect to receive this type of a response, or any for that matter. After some consideration I decide to send every single review a thank you response, but save the suggestions for later. Even though they are great ideas, I want to give the poem a little more time and exposure. Plus, I would like to marinate on the suggestions, really give them though before going ahead and changing the poem I worked so hard on.

After finishing with the emails I try to figure out what to do next. I probably should look up information at how to use the site but there are so many things I could be doing. They even have chat here. Or I could write another poem. What should I do?
11.title: I thank the reviewers, and leave it at that

choices: Improve My Poem
Wander Around Writing.Com
112.content:
I clicked on the chat button to see where it took me. It told me I had to have a basic membership or higher to enter chat. Membership? Huh?

I was confused about the membership and chat, so I exited out of chat and went back to "My Account". Right now, this place was confusing me, but I was having fun. I should try to figure it out some more... I thought.

While I was looking at some of the links (and hoping not to get lost!) I noticed I had one new email. Curious, I opened the email and I was gifted a three-month upgrade membership from RAOK.

I was glad I got a membership, but what was RAOK? And why did they give me a membership? Me, of all people?

Happy, I clicked on the chat button again, read the rules, checked the box and entered chat. I was in "The Lobby" I clicked on the icon at the top that resembled a door.

I scrolled to the bottom of the page and clicked on a random room that had people in it.

Then, suddenly, lots of people were saying "hi" or just my username. I said "hi" back and continued chatting with them. While I was chatting, I was told, by the system, I got a new review. I went to my email, and woulda look at that. I got another review on my poem. I clicked on it to read it and the review was warm and fuzzy, but also very helpful. The reviewer told me if I made changes, they would come back and re-review it for me.

"I am liking this place," I said out loud. Since I had gotten a lot of reviews on my poem telling me how I should change it, I thought about going to improve my poem. Or, I could wander around writing.com
112.title: I click the chat button to see where it takes me.

choices: What do you do in order to keep yourself in creative mood?
How much entering different contests helped your own writing?
113.content:
I rarely can do multitasking on the site. I'm one of those people who can't write with any kind of sound or distraction of any sort in the background. I can't even have multiply tabs open in my browser. When I decide to sit and write something, doesn't matter poetry, story or even blog entry, I switch off the music, close myself in the room and I don't respond to anyone. When we had chat option here before, I hung around every single day with Charlie and Adi. I remember that time Charlie and I did a lot of blogging and when I felt like writing my daily entry I had to leave chat completely in order to focus myself on the daily prompt. If you are a member of any blogging group on the site you know that, in order to participate in monthly challenge, you have to write entries based on daily prompts. These prompts usually don't require from you to be creative, they are mostly expressing your opinion about certain theme, object and they don't require too much of writing effort. However, I was still like: "Okay guys, I have to go and write my entry for today. I'll be back in about hour and a half" while Charlie for example could write his entry and, at the same time, have a conversation with both of us in chat. So, yeah, on Writing.Com I can only do one thing at the time. Everything else I'd need a huge amount of effort and be completely free from any real life obligations in order to succeed through the monthly long writing challenges (one such example is also "Game of Thrones" ).

There are so many interesting features, activities, contests on the site that provide great fun. Sometimes, when I really have nothing to do or if I suffer some kind of writer's block, I scroll down pages of forums and groups to see if there is anything I haven't seen before. I love to run into activities that are created long time ago and are no longer active. Most of the time I scroll through the pages of authors who can't be seen around on a daily basis, who don't enter contests, who don't participate in popular activities and people who I never got the chance to exchange email with, review or something. It amazes me the quality of work in their portfolio and I wish them to get involved in the community little bit more, to let their writing be noticed or just be like some kind of refreshment when it comes about public newsfeed.

I usually write when I feel like writing. I don't believe in "If you want to get somewhere you have to keep writing all the time". This kind of thinking doesn't apply for me because I can't just write whatever and pile up my portfolio with numerous drafts which I would probably delete at some point. I admit that there are times when I come up with, to me, awesome lines and thoughts that I can use in my poetry and of course I store them in notepad or my private blog for creative ideas but that's the hardest I can go when it comes about writing whatever for the sake of staying in writing mood. Lately, I wrote plenty of poetry for the contests on the site. While I think this is great because it keeps me focused, it also distracts me because these aren't poems I really want to write. I write them only for the sake of whatever prompt is given. I guess this can happen when you don't have a writer's goal, something you always go back to because you have plans regarding publishing maybe or when you didn't establish your own writing style, mood and you like to explore different things in order to get one which is my case.

So, when I decide to write another poem, it is usually because I just suddenly, with no specific reason, feel like writing .
113.title: I decide to write another poem.

choices: Order a pizza for dinner.
Start a whole new chapter on a different topic.
Figure out what gift points do.
12.content:
This Chapter was added by my friend Jennifer, who has since left WDC for personal reasons.

I follow the reviewer's suggestions to add the word "pizza" to the end of my poem. I am not sure of what pizza has to do with my poem, but if they think it will sound better...I will do it.

I post ten more poems and receive many more gift points. I have quite a few gift points now. However, I am unsure of what to do with them still.

Oh, while reading through my reviews the person who suggested pizza for my other poem has now given me a suggestion for another. Hmm, he says to add the word "yummy" to the end of my poem. I will do it because he has been a member for two days more than I have, so he must be an expert by now.

His handle is a strange one..."melikeyfoodlots" I wonder what he means by that. I will ask him, when I figure out how to use my email.

Oh, he has sent me one last suggestion: The words "in my tummy." Well, this one is the most strange. I don't see how it relates to my poem about the wonderful blue sky. I will add it though, wouldn't want to turn down expert advice.

Wait! I think Mr. melikeyfoodlots has sent a message with all these suggestions. I put the words together and they say "Pizza, yummy in my tummy!" There is no way that this guy is a poetry expert.

I think I will be more careful in using suggestions from now on.

Hmm...Pizza does sound good right now...
12.title: Using Suggestions

choices: Besides reviews, how else do you use gift points?
123.content:
Because I get many reviews on my new entries, probably because I offer a goodly amount of gift points, my stories are often picked to pieces.

If the review is poorly written or contains what I call teener text talk, I simply delete it and move on.

If the reviewer sends me constructive criticism without rewriting my whole entry to suit their own style of writing and took the time to proofread their email review, I will save the comments and suggestions in a Word member for later editing of the story.

If they are new to my portfolio, I first go to their port to see what type of writer they are. This tells me which of my other stories they might find interesting. I use this to include a link to other items in my portfolio. For example, if they write children's stories, I send them a link like below:

Stories about Fred, feline extraordinare  (E)
My Fred the cat stories
#1283920 by J. A. Buxton (161)


If they write poetry, something I don't write, I simply send them a link to the following:

 Why do I write? Who am I?  (E)
A brief look at me - my life, likes, and dislikes.
#1170755 by J. A. Buxton (161)


Finally, I send them a link simply to my portfolio's home page.

I always try to send a polite reply to my reviewers, both newbies and faithful readers, since they took the time to review something I wrote.
123.title: Figure out what gift points do.

choices: How do YOU use gift points?
How do you get involved on WDC?
Who has influenced you most here on WDC?
1231.content:
When not hoarding gift points like the mighty dragon Smaug ... I love to spoil friends and my adopted newbies! Little surprises in their inboxs make them smile and me in return. There is nothing like finding just the right gift. I like prize packages that include reviews, awardicons, and encouraging c-notes.

I run an Erotica contest with hefty prizes with my GPs and donations. "Erotic Tales of Pleasure & Pain~closed! " 

Another love of mine is Raffles! I tend to have a weeeeee bit o' luck in raffles and guessing games. So I support WDC various charities by purchasing tickets for myself and various friends. Ohh and knowing that others love gift points as much as I do, it always fun to offer a lump sum of GP's with something else enticing such as memberships or merit badges as an Auction Package to help out friends and charity!

My beloved twin Adriana Noir loves a little BLING! So I like to spoil her with shiney awardicons and sparkling trophys.

There is just sooo many things to do with GPs!
1231.title: Besides reviews, how else do you use gift points?

choices: What is your favorite thing about WDC?
What is your least favorite thing about WDC?
12311.content:
Most of the time I save my GP to purchase my membership renewal but some other ways I have spent GP are charity auctions, gift packages, custom signatures, holiday c-notes for friends, raffles. My daughter had a birthday recently and I was short on cash so I actually purchased her a gift from the WDC shop with GP I had earned reviewing. I bought her some lovely stationary and cards. She was thrilled. Plus, it really helped me out in a pinch.

I love the WDC gift point system. I think it is wonderful how you can earn GP doing reviews or entering writing contests. It makes the process encouraging and fun. The old saying it is better to give than receive is so true. The GP system allows people like myself (low income) to give back, that can afford no other means. There is no greater satisfaction than contributing to a great cause, and the WDC community is a truly great cause.
12311.title: How do YOU use gift points?

choices: Handling rude members
Organizing your WdC e-mail
My favorite activities
12312.content:
The best way to get involved is through reviewing. After all, we are all here to share our writing, and hopefully get feedback. Some of us, such as myself, enjoy being part of a larger writing group online, because of that honest feedback. It is through that feedback that we improve as writers.

Speaking of reviewing. If you are new, make sure to check out the many member created review groups on the site. The site already awards reviewers with reviews over 250 characters, but you have the opportunity to earn even more gps. Plus many of these review groups offer excellent prizes and fun activities.

Another way to get involved is to take part in member created groups and contests. You can search them by type by clicking, "search by type", which is located on the left. Whatever your genre or type of writing, there is most likely a group or contest that fits you. Most contests offer rewards, rather it be gps, ribbons, or badges.

Some of these groups and contests are funded by auctions and/or raffles. This is a writing community with members who have plenty of imagination, which makes some of these raffles quite fun and interesting.

Many members have blogs. Stopping by to give them a read, helps you get to know the fellow author. Just make sure to leave a comment, letting them know you paid a visit.

The more involvement you have with fellow members, rather it be groups, contests, activities, responses, or reviewing, the more likely others will view your writing. Just as in life offline, if you never give in return, others tend to stop giving back. So, take the time to become active with your fellow members.

287 Words
12312.title: How do you get involved on WDC?

choices: What are your reviewing strengths?
Do you take part in site contests/activities?
What is your favourite WDC forum?
12313.content:
It's hard to say who has influenced me the most. Honestly, there are probably too many to mention. Since joining WDC, I have made so many friends, it's been incredible. Just the experience of being a member and sharing my writing, then getting reviews and reviewing others, has been hugely influential.

Okay, if I have to mention specific people (and it has to be people—person is too restrictive), I would say Hannah ♫♥♫ has been the person I worked closest with. She was my sponsor for the Rising Stars Programme, and we have written a poem and a story together. She has helped me through the Paper Doll Gang programmes, as well. Winnie Kay and mimi1215 have helped me with my punctuation and grammar (though, I still have a way to go!).eyestar~thanks anon! has been a huge influence with setting up and learning how to review. Andy~~getting back to WDC . . . wow, what can I say about that guy? He is a massive inspiration.

~QPdoll , ♥HOOves♥ , and Life's a Beach... says Joey C are fantastic friends. They have influenced me simply by being there.

There are so many other people I could mention. Cinn is an inspiration with her poetry. That's also true for Fivesixer , Whata in Whoville , and ~Minja~ . I've learned a lot from reading their work.

As mentioned above, it's the whole environment of WDC that has helped me to improve my writing. People (in general) are kind and want to help. I've learned so much over the couple of years since I joined. My confidence has grown, too. That was a big problem for me (it still is a problem, just not quite as large). It's been a wonderful experience, in the main part. Fab!
12313.title: Who has influenced you most here on WDC?

choices: What I remember the most when being a newbie is..
I joined WdC mostly because..
123132.content:
I LOVE entering contests and different activities on WdC. There are few reasons for that; first reason is awards. Who doesn't like awardIcons and MBes? There is some satisfaction when your work is recognized this way, when you manage to get into top three among so many awesome authors on the site. It gives you some kind of hope that there is probably a great writer somewhere inside of you who might as well become greater than the site contests one day. I usually don't enter contest with confidence, thinking my work is much better than anyone else's, no. My first thought when I submit entry is that I am positive sure someone will read what I just wrote, even if those views are from the judges only. I love to see people's interest in whatever I write. Even when I post something in the newsfeed, like blog entry for example, I get views quickly even if I don't receive a lot of comments. I'm okay with that because I also read a lot around the site but don't comment too much on anything. But I know someone is interested in reading and that's what's the most important to me on WdC.

Second reason why I love entering different contests and activities is that I STILL haven't found my own writing style and exploring variety of genres, themes, and types help me to find what suits me the most. When I just joined the site, my first and primal idea was to work on my biographical novel. However, that became long forgotten dream because I run into different obstacles regarding theme of the novel and I got distracted by real life as well. There was also language barrier since I'm not native English speaker. One year later I felt like completely different person with completely different writing goals and my 50k words first draft is collecting dust in my portfolio. What I'm doing right now, I don't know. Few months ago I set the goal for myself; I started to write poetry about grief and its influence after dad died with intention to publish a book of poetry one day but right now I'm in some confusing state of mind because, again, real life's issues (like job, school) that are blocking the creative side of me. I can see this book also being tossed aside. My main problem is that my writing isn't fictional and if I don't live through something I lose creativity. This is also one of the reasons why I enter different contests on the site because I really hope one day I'll manage to find fictional writing style that won't disappear as soon as I stop to feel.

When it comes about activities, I do them for fun as well. Different kind of fun of course. They help me to keep myself present on the site, to do things I normally wouldn't do (like writing 130 reviews in one month ) and similar stuff. WdC is great community, full of awesome writers and nice people who make those activities even more fun than they already are. I can appreciate that.
123132.title: Do you take part in site contests/activities?

choices: What member has been most influencial and why?
What qualities do you appreciate most in a review?
What was your best experience as a new member?
1231321.content:
I first joined this amazing writing community in October of 2013. Honestly, I didn't even read much of anyone else's writing. I just posted five chapters of a poorly written novel. After a week of noticing a few views, but no reviews, I disappeared for a few months. When I logged on, I had one rating, with no review. And that rating was three stars. Now I realize the writing had several issues, but at the time, my ego was quite hurt. I spent a lot of effort on the writing and was quite proud of it. The least the person could have done is tell me how I could improve it. So, I did something that is a bit rude, I e-mailed the person asking them what the issue was. A few days later, there was a curt response that included, "I just didn't like it."

For some reason, I stuck around, adding my poetry to my portfolio. I entered Dark Dreamscapes with a darker piece, but didn't win. Eventually, I began reading items that were rewarded to see what I was lacking. Still, my time on here was extremely limited. The first year, I might have come on here two or three times a month. After being a member for about six months, I finally got an extensive review on my novel showing me the errors in the plot, which became clear that it needed a lot of editing.

It wasn't until being a member for a full year that I actually conducted my first review. I wouldn't call it extensive, but it was to the point offering what I considered honest feedback. The memory of the lack of clarity from my first reviewer in comparison to the second more helpful review stuck in my mind. Knowing how that felt, I did offer suggestions. Though, I probably only conducted ten or so reviews in a years time.

In 2015, I began sharing more of my writing here, and moved on to an upgraded membership, so that I could have more space for my writing. That is also when I began reviewing regularly. At first it was a selfish endeavor, because I realized that noticing others encouraged them to read my writing. Then I realized that finding the strengths and weaknesses in the writing of others actually helped me improve on my own writing. Before I knew it, I was making some very good friends, some of which were instrumental in helping me improve my writing skills.

By 2016, I was heavily active in the site. Some might call it an addiction. There are so many activities available that it can be quite distracting. The more member created activities that I got involved with, the more I seemed to branch out into other genres and forms of writing.

Last year I was moved up to Preferred author, which is acquired through being active writing and reviewing. That is a long way from the woman you posted a novel and disappeared for months at a time. So far, as of now, September of 2017, I have now conducted 655 reviews, a large portion of those quite extensive. And, I have almost 200 items in my port. Quite a long way in comparison to 2013 when I first joined.

Word Count: 548
1231321.title: What I remember the most when being a newbie is..

choices: Tell us about any of your unpleasant experiences here on WDC (if any  )
Tell us about your happiest moment here on WDC
12313212.content:
Reviews are an excellent way to help others improve as well as improve your work. I didn't really believe that before but since the last two years, I have actually witnessed this on my own,how my work is improved by reviewing others' works. I pick up their mistakes and points and when I am writing mine, I remember those points and try to avoid them.

Well, I do like reviews and receiving them, no matter what kind of a review it is. I care that the other person has read my work and has taken the time out to let me know of that in a review, whether it is a thorough one or a short, small five lined one.

However, if I were to choose the qualities and things that I really, really appreciate in a review then they would be:

1. Honesty:
I want to know what the reader thought of my work, I don't want a fluffly, pink review full of praises and applauds without any reason. i'd like to know exactly what the reader liked, what he didn't like, what could be improved, why he liked the story or the poem and how he related to it.

2. Improvement:
My stories or poems are far from perfect, I know that and accept it especially because English is my second language and I do not have much knowledge about English punctuation and its proper usage. However, I am learning it along the way and it is one of the most important things that I see in a review and deeply appreciate.

I want the reviewer to tear apart my work and give me pointers, hints, ways to further improve my work and take it to another level. I don't just want a suggestion or a correction, I appreciate reviews in which they have written in detail why I should change my oriignal sentence to what and why and how it is better in the other way around.

3. Emotions
I love to know how the readers felt after reading my work or about my work. I appreciate reviews that tell me how my work made me feel, how their mood was influenced, if a tear or two came to their eyes or perhaps they laughed, smiled, felt very emotional, teary eyed, hurt, pained. Another thing that I think comes under Emotions would be relating to my work. I'd like to know if the reader was able to relate to my work and in what way.

These are the things I really love to see in reviews I get and appreciate them too!

436 words
12313212.title: What qualities do you appreciate most in a review?

choices: Do you visit General Discussion and Noticing Newbies forums? If you do, why?
What is your worst experience with a newbie?
What is your best experience with a newbie?
123132121.content:
There is one unpleasant situation I had with a newbie that I will always remember and I got myself involved in it while doing reviews of course. I don't quite remember which year it was, maybe two years ago or even last year, I don't know. I remember I was doing reviews for The Newbie Welcome Wagon so I, of course, checked public "Read a Newbie" page in order to find some writing. I usually review poetry and sometimes short stories that count 500 or more words. Very rarely I review flash fiction because most of the time I don't know what to say in a review, especially if I need to reach 1000 characters count. Anyway, I clicked to this random flash fiction (or whatever that was) and decided to share my thoughts about what I just read. The thing is, the story I read wasn't really a story. It was more like random notes, or thoughts, like, just few paragraphs about something that is the beginning of one's writing. It did have the main idea, it just looked like it wasn't finished. Don't ask why I even read it and not to mention review such thing haha. I thought people post their writing on the site in order to receive someone else's opinions or something and the fact such writing was available for reviewing I thought this author expected opinions of course. That's what I do here on the site anyway- if my writing is available to everyone's eyes and opinion I expect someone will care enough to share their own. If I get random book or poetry ideas I write them down in my private blog that isn't available to anyone's eyes and later I use them when writing something useful from it.

I don't remember what the story was about but I will never forget the awkward writing style and lack of punctuation. If you ever received a review from me or if you check my public review page, you'll see that I'm not really harsh in my reviews. I always share good points and things I didn't find appealing while reading in order to keep the balance in a review. Same happened with this newbie's writing. I started with regular greeting and made a good points of the story first before continuing with suggestions which focused mostly around writing style and lack of punctuation, not the story itself. I think I gave it 3 stars rating which now I think was too high for such writing. The response I received was obnoxious. This newbie finished screaming at me, saying how she is ill and because of her illness she couldn't write the story much better. I thought someone is making a really bad joke with me because I don't know any kind of illness that prevent people from using punctuation in their writing . I replied to her that I think she needs to calm down and that this is just my personal opinion as I think punctuation in writing is crucial element. She then replied threatening how she will report me to the site owners how I'm being rude and how I harase her after which I realized she is some sort of psycho so I finished blocking her. To this day I have no idea what was that all about. I think I still have her username in my block list but I didn't check it out ever since to see if she's still on the site.

Since then I rarely do reviews for newbies because I know how sensitive they can be and I try to keep myself away from these kind of people. I even stopped with greeting and meeting them around the site or newbies forums. I know this is a really weird newbie case and it doesn't mean everyone is obnoxious like this author but, since then, I can't make myself to go out there willing to meet our newest members on the site.
123132121.title: Tell us about any of your unpleasant experience...

choices: What are your reading preferences on the site?
What are your writing preferences on the site?
Why do you think people create secondary accounts?
12313213.content:
I think the best thing that happened to me when I was a newbie is that I gained readers and reviewers very soon. I signed up with the idea of writing a biographical novel about life of a crew member on board the cruise ship which turned out to be unique idea because back then there weren't any writers of this sort (I think). Back in November 2013, "The Newbies Academy Group"  was just established under ~ Sisco ~ Back! 's command and I became a member right away where I met couple of great people who helped me with finding the way around. There was Cinn who provided one of the best guidance and who wasn't bothered at all with any kind of questions I and other newbies back then had. Also Angels in my Ear , who was one of the leaders of NAG. This is one of the oldest and also bestest memories I have about being a newbie because I felt really welcomed and important for having them close. And being a member of such wonderful group of people helped me being noticed around which is, I believe, the primal thought for any newbie when they first join some writing community; to gain readers, reviewers and draw attention to their writing portfolio overall.

Few weeks after, Patrick invited me to join his awesome reviewing group, "Invalid Item"  where I learned a lot about reviewing and writing overall through his monthly newsletters that he put together with couple of more great authors. It was a wonderful organization and one of my favorite activities on the site ever invented. I was featured as a writer and reviewer couple of times, I got more traffic in my port and couple of more friends who are still around. As soon as I lost my newbie status (6 months period) I got promoted to preferred author. I wasn't around too much when it happened because I was busy with work and real life but I remember the excitement and also confusion when I Iogged in one day and saw my case color turned yellow. I knew what case colors represent before it happened but I didn't think I deserved promotion because I was more away than I was present on the site and my writing skills weren't really good, my English was, kind of, bad and after I got back to work I wasn't thinking too much about writing or coming here more often. Promotion to preferred author was something that dragged me back in again. This kind of site's promotions have a special charm every time someone's case color change and, considering what each color represent on Writing.Com, it makes you feel more important of course and you get some kind of responsibility to keep doing good job in the future as well. So, overall, my best experience as a new member was that I was lucky enough to meet people kind enough to help me being noticed in my first month and people from who I could learn a lot about writing and reviewing and who shaped me into a member I am today .
12313213.title: What was your best experience as a new member?

choices: Do you feel you give more time to WDC than real life?
Is any of your family member on WDC or into writing?
1231322.content:
When I was thirteen years old, I had written a lot of short stories that were less than 500 words as part of my English in O levels. I started writing poetry, short and simple ones. Then in 2013, I decided to do something about my writing. I wanted to show my writing to other people and get some feedback on them, like how they are, what is wrong with them, what could be improved, and most of all, I wanted to read what kind of stories and poetry others have written.

I started searching in February best online writing websites and after days and days of searching, I found Writing.Com along with another website. It was down to these two and I decided to go with WDC instead of the other website. I remembered the name but I have forgotten it now.

I am very, very glad that I chose WDC over the other website because there is not even a second that I regret having spent here. I have not only shown my writing to a larger audience but also got the opportunity to read the word of other people and reviewing them.

195 words
1231322.title: I joined WdC mostly because..

choices: Are you addicted to WdC?
What are your favorite WdC activities?
What contests do you enter the most and why?
12313222.content:
I guess you could say that an interest in the arts is genetic for me. The father that genes that is part of my genetic make-up, wrote music and poetry. He was quite talented in these ways, but I was not raised by him. I met him when I was much older, after I had already taken interest in art and writing. Though, it is interesting how you can be so much like a parent, when you are not even raised around them.

From the age of three until the age of seven, my mother was married to a decent man, who played guitar. Mostly what he sang were tunes by other musicians, but occasionally he would write his own when he was moved to do so. Since he saw value in the arts and individuality, he encouraged my imagination. And boy did I have one! I was an odd child!

In the present, nobody around me likes to write, so I suppose that is one of the aspects that encourages me to keep logging on. It is refreshing to be around those who, much like me, express themselves in the written word.

This does not mean that I don't have anyone that supports me being a writer. My current boyfriend is pretty amazing with his encouragement. He may not like to write, but he's got a demented imagination, like mine, if not even more distorted. So, I often throw around ideas with him. He comes up with some interesting concepts and he's got quite the sense of humor. It was his idea to give the character in my vampire story a heavy flow and to die in the tampon isle.

Soon, I will be moving to Austin, where there are more supportive people that have similar interests as me, which is a more supportive environment for my creative endeavors. Living out in the country, very few are like me, so I am excited about the change.
12313222.title: Is any of your family member on WDC or into wri...

choices: Your favourite writer on WDC
Your favourite poet on WDC
123132221.content:
That's a question to which there is a definite answer, YES, YES, YES and yes! I am totally addicted to WDC but I believe it is a healthy addiction, you know. Better writing than getting addicted to drugs, smoking and other bad stuff, right? Kidding, I believe it is the best addiction you can have with minimum harm.

A few years back when I first joined WDC, I literally learned WritingML, putting items in my port, sending reviews, posting on forums etc in a day when it takes a good few weeks for a newbie to see, check out everything and see what has been going on and how to do different things.

I did not own a laptop then and I was crazy to review on raid days when it was raiding on weekends with WDC Power Reviewers. I had an iPad but everyone in the house shared it. I remember how I wrote reviews on mobiles and iPad within minutes and send them out, one after the other, without caring about the time. Hell, I'd keep sending reviews until I was lying on the bed and everything had been done except for me to asleep. Now when I recall those days, I can't help face palm myself virtually and laugh!

I am not that addicted now but I believe I have trouble when two or three days have passed and I haven't logged into my WDC account and checked my inbox. Writing. Com is facebook for me, it has everything I need and I spend more time here than anywhere else on the internet.


268 words
123132221.title: Are you addicted to WdC?

choices: So tell me, who is your favorite author on the site?
I published my book thanks to Writing.Com community.
1231322212.content:
It's not a secret that my favorite poet on WdC is Charrr ðŸŒˆ . That's, actually, how I met Charlie here- through his poetry. We didn't know each other right away even though we are only around two months apart from the time we first signed up to this site. I was pretty much away first few months because I had to go back to work so we weren't talking to each other or knew each other well. I think I remember I made a post about tattoos once and he joined discussion we had. Then he signed up to "Give It 100!"  together with Kylie where they said they will do hundred poems in hundred days. Meanwhile it was my time to go back to work again but I kept logging on here to read and comment on those entries he stored to, now, my favorite poetry collection; "Fragments of Being" . Little by little we started to communicate through emails, comments, and IMs and his poetry started to seem more clear to me when I got familiar with the background of each. It is usually said that poetry isn't written to be understood but simply loved, though you need to admit that knowing from where the author gets his inspiration helps you more in understanding his writing because most of the readers desire to know what the writing is all about rather than being completely confused after they finish with reading.

WdC has a lot of worthy authors and poets. I think the reason why Charlie is my favorite is because I can feel whatever he writes about which is something I appreciate the most in any author. That is usually what determine a great author in my opinion; ability to make readers feel for their writing. I can easily recognize his writing anywhere because, to me, it has a unique tone and mood. Sometimes when he is busy with school or just real life overall, and when he doesn't post a lot of writing on the site, I start to miss it. I usually go and read his old poetry when I miss it or I tell him to write something new . Sometimes I tell him I'm his biggest fan and we laugh at how creepy it sounds but he still knows it is true. I wish he consider to publish poetry book because I know it would be successful and I would love to have it on my book shelf in case something happens with his online portfolio. Well, we usually don't think about leaving this place but we never know what may happen in the future. I think I would literally die if his writing disappear just like that since his portfolio is the only portfolio I go back to and his writing is the only writing on the site I have read couple of times.

Anyway, basically, this is why Charlie is my favorite poet on the site- I can always read his writing because each time I can feel something and I am never bored with reading his stuff over and over again .
1231322212.title: Your favourite poet on WDC

choices: I write a second version using the suggstions and post both on my port.
My best experience on WDC so far is...
My worst experience on WDC so far is...
A funny thing happened to me on WDC.
A sad thing happened to me on WDC.
13.content:
I like my poem the way it is. I wrote it from my mind and heart and it says exactly what I want to say. Even though a lot of the words are similar and I do not use punctuation in my poem, I still prefer it the way it is. Some even suggested a different rhyme scheme for my poem.

I write an email to each reviewer thanking them for their reviews and suggestions. I assure them that I appreciate their suggesions and will consider them the next time I write a poem. I want this poem to speak to others with my voice.
13.title: I don't follow the reviewers' suggestio...

choices: Qualities of the best review received
Qualities of the worst review received
What makes a great reviewer?
133.content:
One of the aspects of a larger community, is that everyone has their own individual belief systems. In many cases, people are quite intense about their beliefs, especially when politics come into play. This past election, displayed just that.

I lean more conservative, but I also have what some might call liberal values. More exact, I like to call myself a financial conservative, and I think the government should stay out of our business, especially when it comes to our sexuality and what drugs or food we choose to put in our own bodies. I'm also pro gun and I own a few. I am a Texas gal, ya know.

In this past election, there were some angry people, many of which took out their thoughts towards the conservative over the newsfeed. Some of the opinions seemed quite hateful, and although my friends here for the most part had no knowledge of my personal political beliefs, I took it as a personal attack. My feelings got a bit hurt.

The result was, I chose not to read any blogs or look at my newsfeed until all the hype had faded. In reality, they were just venting, which is their right. It was not a personal attack, but when you develop what you consider close friendships, sometimes emotions can get the best of you in such situations.

Even though I had an issue during that time, I am glad that I stuck around. This is an amazing place to mingle with other writers and enhance personal writing skills. So despite any conflict that has risen over conflicting viewpoints, I still love WdC and appreciate the amazing friendships I have developed with fellow members.

Word Count: 282 words
133.title: My worst experience on WDC so far is...

choices: Review a reviewer whose works are not up your alley
Review an imperfect story or poem
Review a gem (perfect story in your opinion)
14.content:
I decided that since so many people have given their precious time to comment on my poem, I should return the favor At first, I looked at the portfolios (wow, that sounds so professional) of the people who reviewed my personal treasure. However, I found that their taste in literature is not the same as my own.

Feeling that I should still repay the kindness given to me, I continued to search the site for items that I would like to review. It was then that I found the keyword option when looking for something to read. I inputed a topic that I enjoy and I was rewarded with a list of over a hundred stories, poems, books, and other items related to my keyword. I went through the list and it was a mixed bag. Some of the items are perfectly written but use an overdone theme. Others have a provocative idea behind them but are filled with typos and grammatical errors. A few are true gems, perfect in every way.

Finally I discovered something called the review request page. These are people who really want my input. While I didn't put my poem on this page, I probably would have if I had known about it.
14.title: Reviewing

choices: Review a piece recommended by the 'random read' generator.
Review a good friend's story or poem that you absolutely hate.
Review a story or poem that someone wants to publish you don't think is ready.
141.content:
Let's get something straight. I pride myself on my honesty and consider myself a well-read and open-minded person. I read and write in almost any genre: comedy, mystery, scifi, fantasy, historical fiction, romance, horror. I have even dabbled in poetry and written some non-fiction. The one thing I do not read or write is inspirational, specifically spiritual literature.

I am not a religious person so I don't feel qualified to comment on articles of faith. Imagine my surprise when I start reading a beautiful poem with the intention of writing a review, only to discover it is about the author's faith in God. I stop reading immediately. I can't review this. I don't know anything about God or faith or any of that stuff. What if I accidentally insult the author in my review? It would be like insulting their religion. My cursor hovers over the 'X' tab but something stops me from closing the poem.

This person has posted this poem on the review request page, which means they are looking for honest opinions, and I pride myself on my honesty. I can't not review it now. It would be a cop-out; so much for honesty. I decide to treat the poem like any other. I will read it and give an honest review.

I start my review with the disclaimer that I am not a religious person so I will not comment on belief. I will limit my comments strictly to the quality of the writing and the impressions it made. As I wrote the review I quickly came to the realization that though I didn't share the author's faith I truly admired and enjoyed their poem. It was beautifully written and left me with a joyful feeling. It was very uplifting. I told them as much in my review.

I sent off the review expecting a curt, 'Thanks for the review,' if anything in return. What I received back was a long letter of appreciation for the review. The author told me they were grateful I reviewed the poem despite the difficulty. They said their work gets very few reviews and they believe it's because their work is always about their faith and extremely personal. The author loved my review and told me it meant even more to them BECAUSE I am not religious. If the poem was uplifting and joyous to me then that was a wonderful accomplishment. The writer considered my review the most encouraging they had ever received.

It just goes to show that there are people that sincerely want to hear your opinions, no matter how much you may think otherwise. Don't be afraid to say what you think when asked. Be respectful but honest and you maybe surprised what you learn in return.
141.title: Review a reviewer whose works are not up your a...

choices: Describe the most memorable review you have ever written.
Describe the best review you have ever received.
Describe the most difficult thing you have ever reviewed.
1411.content:
I will never forget how thrilled I was when I learned about the 'random read' generator. No more pouring through tons of titles trying to decide what to review. I would simply leave it to chance. Brilliant! I silently vowed I would review anything that came up no matter what genre or how poorly written. With nail-biting trepidation, I pressed the dice icon and fate presented my first random piece for review. It was a wonderful little 12 line poem that I enjoyed very much. I sent out the review feeling elated and anxious to see what came next. I pressed the dice icon again. Oh boy...

There was a short story of moderate length on the screen in front of me. I looked at the content rating, XGC. Okay, that doesn't really bother me. I am not offended by language and my favorite genre to read and write is horror, which gets pretty graphic. I read the title. No help there just a couple of names. The story could be about anything. I read the description line. Uh oh, erotica. This could be trouble. I swore to review whatever appeared so I strengthen my resolve and start to read. Oh no... my goodness... oh my word...

I'm no prude, but the more I read the warmer my face feels. I know I am blushing like a school girl. How am I going to write a review of this when I am not even comfortable reading it in mixed company? I feel a headache coming on. Once again, I renew my determination and try to think of polite ways to discuss the explicit nature of the story. After two grueling hours of tiptoeing over eggshells I finish my review. I am satisfied it is honest and tactful. I send it off, and breathe a sigh of relief. I do NOT push the dice icon again.
1411.title: Review a piece recommended by the 'random r...

choices: The next morning I log on quickly before leaving for work
In the afternoon I find that the author I reviewed has send me an e-mail
While eating Chinese takeout the next evening, I explore WDC more thoroughly
142.content:
After placing my own item up on "Please Review" , I decide to read one of the stories. I click on one titled, Afterlife, which I find out is the first chapter of a novel in progress. It is a ghost story and I enjoy creepy ghost stories.

Grabbing a fleece blanket from the living room, I walk back to my computer and hunker down. I soak up the words of the story. The plot is not unusual, but the writing is fair and as it's dark outside now, I shiver a few times as the main character hears creaking stairs, leaky faucets and the sound of a window opening and shutting - when no one is there. The ending has a good twist and I am satifactorily frightened. I only wish that I hadn't had to wade through so many spelling errors to get through the piece.

Knowing that I appreciate constructive criticism, I decide to review the entire novel, telling the author what I like about the story first. I tell her that I know it's a novel in progress, but I have some suggestions that may help, and I point out two dozen spelling errors and the fact that the plot could be a little more creative, to better capture the reader's attention in the beginning. I tell her that it was definitely a ghost story that impacted me - I am afraid of falling asleep in the dark now and will keep a light on throughout the night!

Tentitavely, I press the "send" button and my review disappears, floating through cyberspace to its intended location. Sighing heavily, I note that I have been in my cramped chair for hours and have forgotten to eat dinner. But the workday is fewer than eight hours away and I must get some sleep.

Reluctantly, but bleary-eyed, I log off Writing.com and then I close down my computer, shutting off my plug strip to help the environment. Tomorrow is another day for reading and writing...
142.title: Review an imperfect story or poem

choices: Your experience in negative review of your piece?
Other extraordinary experiences?
Tell how you review another newbie's piece?
1422.content:
The author I reviewed sent an email telling me that the poem has a double-spaced and that it's normal. Since, I am newbie I accepted his reason and go on browsing until I posted at least 5 poems.

I cannot forget the authors that made my stay here in WDC a pleasant thing in my daily life. Ida Matilda and Hunter's Moon gave an honest review and comments that motivated me to go on writing a poem.

So, I browsed and browsed until I came across with the Traditional Poem Contest which I entered at once without reading the mechanics, and besides I don't know how to post in bitem system.

Lots of kind-hearted authors here in WDC, but, also, there are authors that can broke your heart at once, knowing that some authors beforehand gave a 5 star rating but, he, rated you as 1 with no explanation at all. When I am reading such kind of review or comment, within 5 minutes, I have to stop and think about it, then, composed myself again to go on with my writing. Why bothered?

I can do what he can? Why bothered to his not-so-very-ordinary review?
1422.title: In the afternoon I find that the author I revie...

choices: What would you do if someone sent you an anonymous one-star hate review?
If you knew an anonymous hate-review sender, what would you tell him/her?
14221.content:
True story:

The one-star rated review was: " this is interesting and uncalled for but it made a diffrent mind in my head mymy." (True quote)

Now how did I take this review or find words to answer it? I decided to play the fool, as playing the fool is my favorite arms of defense.

So I thanked her for the review and sent some gps. Then I went to her port, picked her best writing, sent her a nice review with 4.5 stars. I wasn't condescending. Her piece deserved it.

She thanked me and never reviewed me again.

I believe turning the other cheek works...usually. At least, it has for me for the eight years I have been a WdC member. The trouble is some one-star hate reviewers review anonymously. For them, I have no defense; I just ignore them.
